title: Remove _mode_to_query, consolidate with QueryRunner
body:
Previously the QueryRunner was only used for recursive queries, and we had a separate _mode_to_query function that was implemented for use by non-recursive queries. Given the redundancy, I decided to consolidate.

Each index subclass can now implement a _preprocess_query if they wish to validate / pass arguments down to query subclasses.

For instance, summary prompts should only have a `text` field, and question-answer prompts should only have a `context_str` and `query_str` field.

title: Add token predictor
body:
[copied from docs]

GPT Index now offers a token predictor, allowing you to estimate your costs during 1) index construction, and 2) index querying, before any respective LLM calls are made.

To do this, import and instantiate the MockLLMPredictor with the following:
```python
from gpt_index import MockLLMPredictor

llm_predictor = MockLLMPredictor(max_tokens=256)
```
Examples
![build](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4858925/208839023-a502760f-1f0e-40ae-83d0-d94f26265f74.png)
![query](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4858925/208839028-02b14fdf-a2ae-4eff-9b0a-57cf26ff178e.png)

title: Refactor token decorator to only be on base class
body:
Previously, #85 needed to include decorators on subclasses as well, for `build_index_from_documents` and some `insert`. This PR does the following:
- abstract out "outer" and "inner" functions for build_index_from_documents so decorator can be put on parent class, while implementation can be on subclass
- pass llm_predictor to GPTTreeInserter (was a prev. bug on my part) so that token counting would work.
- remove llm_token_counter decorator from subclasses

Closes #101

title: Add vector store support (Weaviate, Pinecone, Faiss)
body:
GPT Index now offers multiple integration points with vector stores / vector databases: 

1) GPT Index can load data from vector stores, similar to any other data connector. This data can then be used within GPT Index data structures. `PineconeReader`, `WeaviateReader`, `FaissReader`.
2) GPT Index can use a vector store itself (Faiss) as an index. Like any other index, this index can store documents and be used to answer queries. `GPTFaissIndex`

title: Move all query-related classes to under the query module
body:
Query classes for trees, keyword table, list are now moved under the `gpt_index.indices.query` module. This allows us to prevent circular imports down the road. 
Now, all indices can import from queries, but queries cannot import the index class (they can only import the underlying data structure).

title: Abstract out PromptHelper for splitting/truncating text given prompt limitations
body:
Before, the code for getting the Node chunk size and defining a text splitter was contained within each index class. Also some utilities for joining nodes together were hacky and did not guarantee that the joined node text would not exceed the prompt size. Also, the logic for getting an "empty" prompt to determine the initial prompt length was repetitive and could be abstracted away.

Here, I abstract out a base PromptHelper class - a PromptHelper object is defined under each Index. We can use the PromptHelper to fetch the corresponding text splitter given a prompt. We can also use the PromptHelper to join text from different nodes (for use in the tree index). 

Added unit tests as well.

This should prevent issues like #87 from happening on well-formed text. 

Closes #87

repo.description: LlamaIndex (formerly GPT Index) is a data framework for your LLM applications

title: Add index composability!
body:
This is a big PR that introduces a big feature: index composability. Now, you can layer different index structures on top of each other! For instance, you can define a list index over a document, and then define a tree index over the list! 
```
list1 = GPTListIndex([doc1])
list1.set_summary("<summary1>")
list2 = GPTListIndex([doc2])
list2.set_summary("<summary2>")
tree = GPTTreeIndex([list1, list2])
```
During a query, for instance `tree.query('text', mode='recursive', ...)`, we would first traverse the tree, and when it hits a leaf node that corresponds to a sub-data structure (`list1` or `list2`), we will then proceed to recursively call `query` on that data structure in order to retrieve a response. 

This makes our GPT index structures much more extensible and flexible. 

**Summary of changes**
- Abstracted out a BaseDocument class that both Document (from data loaders) and IndexStruct (our data struct classes) inherit from.
- Add a DocumentStore that contains the id's of all BaseDocuments. Both Document objects and IndexStruct objects are registered in here, allowing us to recursively fetch and query sub-index structures within an index structure.
- Add a reference document id to each Node class. This allows us to recursively query within another index struct after we traverse a node, if the reference document id of that node corresponds to another index struct in the DocumentStore.
- Use Node as the central abstraction containing both "text" as well as a reference document_id: use for List, Tree, KeywordTable
- Factored out a QueryRunner to recursively run queries. I grappled with some circular dependency issues but I believe the current approach works. 
- Add a bunch of unit tests

repo.name: llama_index

title: Token Usage Tracking
body:
### What is this?
From https://github.com/jerryjliu/gpt_index/issues/56. This PR adds support for counting tokens used during calls to the LLM. This is done via the decorator `llm_token_counter()` that lives in `gpt_index/utils.py`. 

At the moment, this decorator can only be used on class instance methods with a `_llm_predictor` attribute.

e.g.
```
    class GPTTreeIndexBuilder:
        ...
        @llm_token_counter("build_from_text")
        def build_from_text(self, documents: Sequence[BaseDocument]) -> IndexGraph:
            ...
```
If you run `build_from_text()`, it will print the output in the form below:
```
    [build_from_text] Total token usage: <some-number> tokens
```

### Why do we need this?
Calls to LLMs such as GPT3 cost money. For example, from OpenAI's [pricing](https://openai.com/api/pricing/), the Davinci endpoint is $0.02 for every 1000 tokens. 

Since gpt_index makes multiple LLM calls when building the index, it's handy to know how many tokens we're going through. 

### Remaining TODOs for this PR
- [x] add tests specific to token tracking. may have to patch the OpenAI object in chain_wrapper.py; we cannot mock the whole LLMPredictor object since we need the `_total_tokens_used` instance attribute to do its thing
- [x] add support for remaining index/query classes that call the LLM
- [x] test with openai billing and usage
- [x] consider adding this change on the abstract class level so that we're not repeating the same code everywhere, or turn it into a decorator ([this](https://towardsdatascience.com/decorating-methods-defined-in-a-class-with-python-4b361589440#:~:text=To%20decorate%20a%20method%20in,the%20integer%20function%20gets%20called.) may be helpful).

### Other comments
Other implementations I considered
* add a variable to the LLM prediction response: adding more seemed complicated. today you'll have 3 return values but what if you have 4 tomorrow
* make a separate class to count this: seemed unnecessary

We might also miss token counts if you call the llm where we're not surrounding with token_start and end. 

### For the future
* estimate cost before running indexing or querying
* actual dollar cost

### Known issues:
Sometimes the token count is off by a few. See this issue for an example: https://github.com/openai/openai-python/issues/150

title: add nodes independently for each document
body:
Before, we just did `"\n".join([d.text for d in documents])`, and passed the entire chunk into our index data structure. 

This PR adds a bit more granularity in how we construct the index, by first iterating through each document and chunking each document up. This prevents cases where we have one chunk corresponding to multiple docs.

title: Add general embedding abstraction
body:
Add general embedding abstraction layer, BaseEmbedding.

OpenAIEmbedding is a subclass of this abstraction. Allow users to pick between davinci, curie, babbage, ada. (NOTE: davinci is stupidly expensive for embeddings! The default is curie). 

Also separate out a notebook purely to test embedding examples.

title: Embeddings improvements: caching + add to List index
body:
Following up on @hongyishi's work on embeddings: 
- Added embedding-based queries to list indices as well. This allows top-k embedding lookup, prefiltering the set of text chunks that we then pass to GPT to create and refine an answer on.
- Added caching to embeddings. These embeddings will be lazily created during query time on a given node, but they will be reused for subsequent queries.

title: Optimize initialization times
body:
Put "heavy" loading operations, such as downloading stopwords or initializing the pretrained tokenizer, into a global variable singleton that lazily loads the tokenizer when called. 

Now there's no need to reinitialize the tokenizer/stopwords etc. whenever a function call is triggered + an index struct is created.

title: [take 2] add insert to tree
body:
Adds insert to tree.

This is a bit more involved than insertion for keyword table or list. Created a separate "Inserter" class to deal with this. 

Tree insertion works by traversing from the root node using an "insert prompt" to select the relevant child node to traverse next. Once we arrive at a leaf node, we insert the new text chunk. If the num_children exceeds the limit, we have an additional consolidation step. 

Added a unit test to assert behavior of tree insertion.

title: Add simple retrieve query for tree index
body:
If GPTTreeIndex is built with query_str, then performing a full traversal to leaf nodes is inefficient compute wise and suboptimal (the answers have already been synthesized by the tree, we shouldn't be digging down into leaf nodes again to synthesize another answer). 

This adds a simpler query mechanism which simply synthesizes the answer from the root nodes.

title: separate query from index structure
body: Separate query functionality into new classes. Add `mode` on query function on all GPTIndex structs. This allows us to have different query classes for the same GPT Index - e.g. different query mechanisms to traverse the same GPTTreeIndex.

title: Refactor main index files
body:
Move current "GPTIndex" class under "GPTTreeIndex" under indices module. Also refactored directory reader into its own abstraction. This paves the way for us to add other data structures.

Other fixes:
- added great gatsby notebook (oops)
- updated readme

repo.name: llama_index
repo.description: LlamaIndex (formerly GPT Index) is a data framework for your LLM applications

title: Add functionality for a branching factor
body:
Adds a child branching factor for each parent node, so that instead of just exploring one child, it has the option to pick multiple children to explore, and refine the answer across multiple children. GPT Index does this recursively at every parent node, offering tons of opportunities to refine and expand the answer! 

Example usage below (with branch factor 2):

![Screen Shot 2022-11-10 at 12 06 32 AM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4858925/201251679-614c14c4-4adf-4454-90e1-05a9c1f065cf.png)

Here's branch factor 1 (the existing approach): 
![Screen Shot 2022-11-10 at 12 05 22 AM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4858925/201251793-5d3546e0-4139-4e6b-b2b6-e5d071d67474.png)

As we can see the answer is much more detailed in the first.
